Comment: As much as I hate Trump and everything he is doing to our country, I don't hate this pick. I read her book. I'm trying to figure out what policy changes she supports that her critics would disagree with?  I feel that the status quo is not working - big pharma and big food corporations have bought everyone - the media, healthcare organizations, universities, political campaigns.   Our kids are served garbage at school. We could help childhood obesity like Japan does, but we choose not to.   Europe, and even China in some cases, have more strict guidelines on what chemicals can be put into our food.   We are thrown drug after drug (and of course they absolutey have thier place and save lives) but overall we are not getting healthier. Life expectancy is going down.   I might give her some side eye for a few things, I am pro vax, but overall she is in support of metabolic health - simple, basic things like eating healthy and exercising, and questioning what is obviously not working in the medical establishment.    I see she didn't finish her residency, but is that qualification necessarily to see all the disfunction in healthcare?  So while Trump is absolutely the worst, I am not sure she is really "the worst". He has definitely made some MUCH worse picks. üò©üòÖ  Convince me otherwise?

Comment: Sometimes, yes.    Being a doctor in general doesn't mean you know that much about any given area of health, nor does it mean that doctor is going to always argue in good faith.  There are topics they BARELY scratch the surface of in medical school, that doctors will never learn more about if they don't specialize in that area of medicine.  It's why you don't go to your cardiologist about a suspicious mole and why you don't ask your ophthalmologist about managing your type one diabetes.  People with a relevant associates degree can easily be more informed and up to date about a particular subject than an MD.  Especially if they have working experience in that field.  Like a nail tech can probably tell you more about your finger nails than a urologist can off the top of their head.  You can also become a "Dr." with a large number of different degrees.  My advice is to try to mostly take advice from doctors who are board certified in the relevant area of practice.

Comment: RE: grifting, I will refer you to a book review who addresses this better than I can. I personally don‚Äôt trust any ‚Äúdoctor‚Äù who no longer practices and instead pushes their image on TV and/or social media even if they are correct on a few things.   But again, I‚Äôd be willing to give her a benefit of a doubt if she actually uses her position to benefit Americans and not her own pocketbook. That remains to be seen:  Review of her book except below:  ‚ÄúBut despite all her talk of conflicts of interest being a problem in healthcare research, she doesn't directly disclose her own: that she owns a company that profits extensively off the claims she's making in the book (like everyone should use a continuous glucose monitor because blood tests are insufficient, and she happens to have a company that makes/sells monitors, prescriptions for monitors, and an app subscription to track your data). Nor does she disclose that her brother/co-author has a healthcare company (he's an MBA, not a clinician) that also profits from the advice and recommendations in the book (and that she's an investor in his company), or that Mark Hyman, MD is the medical advisor for her brother's company and he is quoted extensively throughout her book to support her statements (and he also provided an endorsement/quote for her book separately). Or that the company she recommends readers order their own blood work from is Mark Hyman's new medical startup (and costs about 100x more than ordering your own blood work directly from a lab like Labcorp or Marek would). And after looking on her website, she is an investor in that medical startup (which I don't think she disclosed in the book itself, but I could have missed it). She also promotes basil seeds frequently throughout the book (and she happens to be an investor in a basil seed company that sells them for like $20 per bag, compared to the $2 they cost at an Indian grocer, if you happen to have one nearby). Notice a trend? "Here's a bunch of advice about what you should do, and if you need help, here are places you can go to get an app/device/nutrition/food delivery, and I happen to be an investor in each of these companies that sell these things way over market value!"‚Äù

Ironically, it's a very naive take to assume the only legitimate knowledge you can gain about health is in a medical school classroom or in a few weeks of rotations.  Why do you think general practitioners and even specialists, especially psychiatrists, will send their patients to therapists without medical degrees?  It's because people can learn very specific information and be knowledgeable about that while most doctors have to have extremely broadbased knowledge, even after they begin specializing.  As part of my example you ignored, how long did you study nail health in medical school?  Which USMLE exam did you have to answer about cuticle care and breakage caused by acrylics?  When did you learn about tattoo and piercing aftercare steps?  On which rotation did you focus on the options for reducing hyperpigmentation and fine lines using non-invasive methods?  Nobody is saying doctors aren't smart enough to learn those or dozens of other topics.  It's just that most doctors simply haven't studied them yet, nor will they likely ever.  It's a stupid reason to discount the knowledge gained by people who have devoted decades to these niche topics.    Like, congrats, ten years ago you memorized everything about kidneys and you can still even identify the thalamus on a fuzzy black and white cross section of the brain today within three tries.  But the letters MD or DO after your name don't mean you're the ONLY person that can learn about health related topics in depth.
